content: The Supreme Court put a new limit on police searches of cars Tuesday, saying that "countless individuals guilty of nothing more serious than a traffic violation" have had their vehicles searched in violation of their rights. In a 5-4 decision, the justices set aside a 1981 opinion that had given police broad authority to search cars whenever they made an arrest. Instead, the justices said that an arresting officer could search a vehicle only if weapons were potentially in reach of the suspect or if there was reason to believe that the car contained evidence related to the arrest. For example, if the driver was arrested in a drug crime, the car could be searched for drugs. more here: "http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-scotus-carsearch22-2009apr22,0,1967319.story" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

content: I'm not sure if there is a problem caused by other agencies but I know when I searched cars, it was either; Search incident to an arrest....I could search the immediate area of the person being arrested, basically a reasonable distance that the person could toss evidence if stopped. However, if the car were going to be seized, then the entire car gets searched, period. The other is simply "Conscent". Many drivers feel they can't say "No" when asked for permission to search. Frankly, I was always surprised at those who conscented knowing they had drugs in the car. Often times when a driver says no, the next step for the officer would be to run a dog around the vehicle and see if it alerts to narcotics. If it does, there's your PC to search without conscent. Now the catch is, what length of time is reasonable to have a driver wait for a dog to arrive onscene. That one is up to the courts to decide. Don

If a judge finds out that their alleged PC was weak for a search though(during a check point stop only), he will throw it out. Check points will probably remain, but maybe they will be more limited. title: Supreme Court scales back police right to search cars

content: The Supreme Court put a new limit on police searches of cars Tuesday, saying that "countless individuals guilty of nothing more serious than a traffic violation" have had their vehicles searched in violation of their rights. In a 5-4 decision, the justices set aside a 1981 opinion that had given police broad authority to search cars whenever they made an arrest. Instead, the justices said that an arresting officer could search a vehicle only if weapons were potentially in reach of the suspect or if there was reason to believe that the car contained evidence related to the arrest. For example, if the driver was arrested in a drug crime, the car could be searched for drugs. more here: "http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-scotus-carsearch22-2009apr22,0,1967319.story" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

content: I'm not sure if there is a problem caused by other agencies but I know when I searched cars, it was either; Search incident to an arrest....I could search the immediate area of the person being arrested, basically a reasonable distance that the person could toss evidence if stopped. However, if the car were going to be seized, then the entire car gets searched, period. The other is simply "Conscent". Many drivers feel they can't say "No" when asked for permission to search. Frankly, I was always surprised at those who conscented knowing they had drugs in the car. Often times when a driver says no, the next step for the officer would be to run a dog around the vehicle and see if it alerts to narcotics. If it does, there's your PC to search without conscent. Now the catch is, what length of time is reasonable to have a driver wait for a dog to arrive onscene. That one is up to the courts to decide. Don

title: Supreme Court scales back police right to search cars

content: quote: Originally posted by PSimon572: Now they need to revisit illegal check points. Quick stopping people without probable cause. Did you know, for instance in Florida, a check point stop allows the police to ONLY check safety issues such as a DUI (limited to obvious usually), equipment like lights and tires, drivers license check, but not insurance, registration (making you produce it when it is on your tag - not their alleged reason for stopping you anyway), and they can't investigate criminal activity unless it knocks their eyes out (no searches allowed without consent, but they usually get that consent sometimes by insinuating a search warrant will be promptly obtained within minutes, and you have to wait, which is not true!! Unless they have a reasonable suspicion (easily done admittedly) then they need to pass you on. If a judge finds out that their alleged PC was weak for a search though(during a check point stop only), he will throw it out. Check points will probably remain, but maybe they will be more limited. They are a main source of getting DUI's and drivers license violations, both of which MADD adores, so go figure. No USSC justice wants to be blamed by MADD's network of being light on DUI's.
